cards.title: The Silk Road / Who was the real Dread Pirate Roberts?
cards.rawTitle: Who was the real Dread Pirate Roberts?

item.title: The Silk Road: who was the real Dread Pirate Roberts?
item.trailText: Ross Ulbricht was convicted in February 2015. In the lead up to his sentencing, Deep Web explores whether he was the swashbuckling criminal kingpin he was made out to be in court, or simply a naive tech visionary
item.standFirst:
Ross Ulbricht, the mastermind behind The Silk Road drugs trading website, was convicted in February 2015. In the lead up to his sentencing, Deep Web explores whether Ulbricht was the swashbuckling criminal kingpin he was made out to be in court, or simply a naive tech visionary. Narrated by Keanu Reeves, it questions the FBI's methods in seizing the Silk Road's servers and asks whether the investigation has chilling consequences for state surveillance.

To see more from Deep Web go here
item.byline: Alex Winter, Bond 360, Andy Greenberg, Charlie Phillips, Dan Susman

cards.title: Annual cheese rolling event held in Gloucestershire
cards.rawTitle: Annual cheese rolling event held in Gloucestershire

item.title: Annual cheese rolling event held in Gloucestershire
item.trailText: Thousands gather for one of Britain's Bank Holiday traditions on Sunday, the annual cheese rolling competition in Gloucestershire
item.standFirst: Thousands of people gather for one of Britain's Bank Holiday traditions on Sunday, the annual cheese rolling competition in Gloucestershire. During the event participants must chase a wheel of cheese down a steep 200-metre hill. The competition is a free-for-all and can trace its roots back to the early 1800

cards.title: Nepal earthquake 2015 / At candlelight vigil, a pledge to remember and rise again
cards.rawTitle: At candlelight vigil, a pledge to remember and rise again

item.title: Nepal earthquake: by candlelight vigil, Nepalis pledge to remember and rise again
item.trailText: People gathered in the centre of Kathmandu on Monday to light candles in remembrance of those who were killed by the massive earthquake in Nepal one month earlier
item.standFirst: People gathered in the centre of Kathmandu on Monday to light candles in remembrance of those who were killed by the massive earthquake in Nepal one month earlier, on 25 April. With millions still affected by the disaster which claimed the lives of more than 8,000, World Vision organised the 'light for Nepal' event in the Bhrikutimandap district

stillImage.caption: A woman attends a candlit vigil for the victims of the Nepal earthquake in Kathmandu Photograph: World Vision Photograph: World Vision
stillImage.cleanCaption: A woman attends a candlit vigil for the victims of the Nepal earthquake in Kathmandu Photograph: World Vision

displayImages.caption: A woman attends a candlit vigil for the victims of the Nepal earthquake in Kathmandu Photograph: World Vision Photograph: World Vision

displayImages.cleanCaption: A woman attends a candlit vigil for the victims of the Nepal earthquake in Kathmandu Photograph: World Vision

cards.title: Tuareg life in the Sahara desert
cards.rawTitle: Tuareg life in the Sahara desert

item.title: Tuareg life in the Sahara desert
item.trailText: A new exhibition at the Royal Geographic Society sheds light on the nomadic culture of Mali and Niger as they fight to preserve their way of life
item.standFirst: A new exhibition at the Royal Geographic Society sheds light on the nomadic culture of Mali and Niger as they fight to preserve their way of life

displayImages.caption:
Tuareg
Once only known to Europeans as ‘the blue men of the desert’, the Tuareg have lived in extreme conditions deep in the Sahara for over a thousand years Photograph: Bernus/Bernus Estate
displayImages.altText: Tuareg
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Tuareg
Once only known to Europeans as ‘the blue men of the desert’, the Tuareg have lived in extreme conditions deep in the Sahara for over a thousand years

displayImages.caption:
Tuareg kids
Civil war now threatens their homeland in Niger and northern Mali. The Tuareg, like many nomadic tribes across the world, have suffered at the relatively new concept of national borders Photograph: Bernus/Bernus Estate
displayImages.altText: Tuareg
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Tuareg kids
Civil war now threatens their homeland in Niger and northern Mali. The Tuareg, like many nomadic tribes across the world, have suffered at the relatively new concept of national borders

displayImages.caption:
At the well
The ‘desert rock’ music scene may have given Tuareg bands like Tinariwen and Tamikrest an international spotlight, but knowledge of their culture and plight remains limited in the UK Photograph: Henrietta Butler
displayImages.altText: Tuareg
displayImages.cleanCaption:
At the well
The ‘desert rock’ music scene may have given Tuareg bands like Tinariwen and Tamikrest an international spotlight, but knowledge of their culture and plight remains limited in the UK

displayImages.caption:
The veil
The origin of the Tuareg’s trademark blue allichu veil is open to debate. In addition to giving protection from dust whipped up by desert winds, the veils are believed to prevent bad spirits from entering the body. The dye bleeds freely onto the skin, giving the wearer a blue-grey complexion Photograph: Henrietta Butler
displayImages.altText: Tuareg
displayImages.cleanCaption:
The veil
The origin of the Tuareg’s trademark blue allichu veil is open to debate. In addition to giving protection from dust whipped up by desert winds, the veils are believed to prevent bad spirits from entering the body. The dye bleeds freely onto the skin, giving the wearer a blue-grey complexion

displayImages.caption:
The Sultan of Agadez
Both the cloth and the dye for the allichu veil come from Nigeria, and merchants in camel caravans travel a thousand miles south to the Nigerian towns of Tano and Sokoto to trade. A round trip can take six months, and for accompanying boys – some as young as ten – this is an important rite of passage. In times of peak trade in the 1920s and 1930s, the caravans had up to 20,000 camels Photograph: Bernus Estate
displayImages.altText: Tuareg
displayImages.cleanCaption:
The Sultan of Agadez
Both the cloth and the dye for the allichu veil come from Nigeria, and merchants in camel caravans travel a thousand miles south to the Nigerian towns of Tano and Sokoto to trade. A round trip can take six months, and for accompanying boys – some as young as ten – this is an important rite of passage. In times of peak trade in the 1920s and 1930s, the caravans had up to 20,000 camels

displayImages.caption:
Peace
At the 2001 Festival de l’Aïr in Iferoune in Niger, the Tuareg expressed their wishes for peace – or paix in French, as the banner here says – after ten years of rebellion. But promises made by the Nigerien government were soon broken, and the Tuareg of Niger again rebelled between 2007 and 2009 with devastating consequences Photograph: Henrietta Butler
displayImages.altText: Tuareg
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Peace
At the 2001 Festival de l’Aïr in Iferoune in Niger, the Tuareg expressed their wishes for peace – or paix in French, as the banner here says – after ten years of rebellion. But promises made by the Nigerien government were soon broken, and the Tuareg of Niger again rebelled between 2007 and 2009 with devastating consequences

displayImages.caption:
Dancer
Festival de l’Aïr has become an annual event, and celebrates Tuareg culture through dance, poetry and music. Only Tuareg men take part in these dancing ceremonies. Noblemen do not dance, as this would be considered undignified Photograph: Henrietta Butler
displayImages.altText: Tuareg
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Dancer
Festival de l’Aïr has become an annual event, and celebrates Tuareg culture through dance, poetry and music. Only Tuareg men take part in these dancing ceremonies. Noblemen do not dance, as this would be considered undignified

displayImages.caption:
Malian Tuareg
Tuareg women enjoy equal rights to men, but their main role, as seen here, is looking after their family. When in the company of women, Tuareg men pull up their veils above the nose in a sign of respect Photograph: Jean Marc Durou
displayImages.altText: Tuareg
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Malian Tuareg
Tuareg women enjoy equal rights to men, but their main role, as seen here, is looking after their family. When in the company of women, Tuareg men pull up their veils above the nose in a sign of respect

displayImages.caption:
Family
The exhibition and events series ‘The Tuareg or Kel Tamasheq, and a history of the Sahara’ will be on at the Royal Geographic Society from the 2-20 June Photograph: x
displayImages.altText: Tuareg
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Family
The exhibition and events series ‘The Tuareg or Kel Tamasheq, and a history of the Sahara’ will be on at the Royal Geographic Society from the 2-20 June

cards.title: Four legs good / A history of photographing animals

item.title: Four legs good: a history of photographing animals
item.trailText: Lolcats might be a very modern fixation, but humans have been photographing animals ever since we invented the camera
item.standFirst: Lolcats might be a very modern fixation, but humans have been photographing animals ever since we invented the camera. From Eadweard Muybridge’s galloping horses to the wild dogs of present-day South Africa, the animal world offers an endless source of fascination

displayImages.caption:
Portrait of a Girl with a Deer, around 1854, maker unknown, daguerreotype
Animals began to appear in front of the camera lens soon after the invention of photography in 1839. A new exhibition charts the history of animal photography, from early daguerrotypes to contemporary prints.

• In Focus: Animalia is on at the Getty Centre in Los Angeles from 26 May to 18 October. All photos: The J Paul Getty Museum
displayImages.altText: Portrait of a Girl with a Deer, about 1854, maker unknown, daguerreotype
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Portrait of a Girl with a Deer, around 1854, maker unknown, daguerreotype
Animals began to appear in front of the camera lens soon after the invention of photography in 1839. A new exhibition charts the history of animal photography, from early daguerrotypes to contemporary prints.

• In Focus: Animalia is on at the Getty Centre in Los Angeles from 26 May to 18 October. All photos: The J Paul Getty Museum

displayImages.caption:
The Zebra, Burchell’s, or Dauw (Asinus Burchellii), about 1865, Frank Haes, albumen silver print
Two nearly identical prints made with a double-lens camera and pasted on a card created a three-dimensional image when viewed through a stereoscope. Frank Haes made a reputation for himself by photographing exotic animals at London Zoo.
displayImages.altText: The Zebra, Burchell’s, or Dauw (Asinus Burchellii), about 1865, Frank Haes, albumen silver print
displayImages.cleanCaption:
The Zebra, Burchell’s, or Dauw (Asinus Burchellii), about 1865, Frank Haes, albumen silver print
Two nearly identical prints made with a double-lens camera and pasted on a card created a three-dimensional image when viewed through a stereoscope. Frank Haes made a reputation for himself by photographing exotic animals at London Zoo.

displayImages.caption:
Dead Stag in a Sling, 1850s-60s, Horatio Ross, albumen silver print
A founding member of the Photographic Society of Scotland, Ross was a pioneer of animal photography. He was named after his godfather, Horatio Nelson, a close friend of his father’s.
displayImages.altText: Dead Stag in a Sling, 1850s-60s, Horatio Ross, albumen silver print
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Dead Stag in a Sling, 1850s-60s, Horatio Ross, albumen silver print
A founding member of the Photographic Society of Scotland, Ross was a pioneer of animal photography. He was named after his godfather, Horatio Nelson, a close friend of his father’s.

displayImages.caption:
Galloping Horse with Rider, 1881, Eadweard J. Muybridge, salted paper print
In the early 1880s Leland Stanford, an industrialist and former governor of California, commissioned Eadweard Muybridge to test a theory: that all four hoofs of a horse lift off the ground during a gallop. Muybridge devised a system for simultaneously tripping the shutters of up to twenty-four cameras arranged on a low shelf as the animal advanced across a racetrack. This test succeeded in visually halting the motion of a rapidly moving horse and proving the theory to be correct.
displayImages.altText: Galloping Horse with Rider in Eadweard J. Muybridge, The Attitudes of Animals in Motion, 1881, Eadweard J. Muybridge, salted paper print
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Galloping Horse with Rider, 1881, Eadweard J. Muybridge, salted paper print
In the early 1880s Leland Stanford, an industrialist and former governor of California, commissioned Eadweard Muybridge to test a theory: that all four hoofs of a horse lift off the ground during a gallop. Muybridge devised a system for simultaneously tripping the shutters of up to twenty-four cameras arranged on a low shelf as the animal advanced across a racetrack. This test succeeded in visually halting the motion of a rapidly moving horse and proving the theory to be correct.

displayImages.caption:
Wooden Mouse and Duck, 1929, André Kertész, gelatin silver print
André Kertész bought his first camera and made his first photograph while working as a clerk at the Budapest stock exchange in 1912. After years of amateur snapshot photography in his native Hungary, he moved to Paris in 1925 and began a career as a freelance photographer. There, speaking little French, he took to the streets, wandering, observing, and developing his intimate approach to imagemaking.
displayImages.credit: The J Paul Getty Museum. © Estate of André Kertész
displayImages.altText: Wooden Mouse and Duck, 1929, André Kertész, gelatin silver print
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Wooden Mouse and Duck, 1929, André Kertész, gelatin silver print
André Kertész bought his first camera and made his first photograph while working as a clerk at the Budapest stock exchange in 1912. After years of amateur snapshot photography in his native Hungary, he moved to Paris in 1925 and began a career as a freelance photographer. There, speaking little French, he took to the streets, wandering, observing, and developing his intimate approach to imagemaking.

displayImages.caption:
David Webb, Jeweled Toad, New York, 1963, Hiro, dye imbibition print
In the 1960s, while working for the fashion magazine Harper’s Bazaar, Hiro created a series of photographs of various animals posed with jewelry. Here a small owl with slightly disheveled plumage examines an ornamental toad that it has steadied with one of its talons. The juxtaposition between a live bird and a precious object makes for a whimsical interpretation of a predator and its prey.
displayImages.credit: The J Paul Getty Museum. Purchased with funds provided by the Photographs Council. © Hiro
displayImages.altText: David Webb, Jeweled Toad, New York, 1963, Hiro (Yasuhiro Wakabayashi), dye imbibition print
displayImages.cleanCaption:
David Webb, Jeweled Toad, New York, 1963, Hiro, dye imbibition print
In the 1960s, while working for the fashion magazine Harper’s Bazaar, Hiro created a series of photographs of various animals posed with jewelry. Here a small owl with slightly disheveled plumage examines an ornamental toad that it has steadied with one of its talons. The juxtaposition between a live bird and a precious object makes for a whimsical interpretation of a predator and its prey.

displayImages.caption:
Chong Ju, 1970, Soon Tae Hong, gelatin silver print
The Korean photographer Soon Tae Hong meticulously documented the street life of Seoul from the 1960s-80s. This picture seems much older than it is - testament to the fact that in 1970, Seoul was only just on the verge of transforming into a bustling urban metropolis.
displayImages.credit: The J Paul Getty Museum. © Soon Tae (Tai) Hong
displayImages.altText: Chong Ju, 1970, Soon Tae (Tai) Hong, gelatin silver print
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Chong Ju, 1970, Soon Tae Hong, gelatin silver print
The Korean photographer Soon Tae Hong meticulously documented the street life of Seoul from the 1960s-80s. This picture seems much older than it is - testament to the fact that in 1970, Seoul was only just on the verge of transforming into a bustling urban metropolis.

displayImages.caption:
Out of the Box, 1971, William Wegman, gelatin silver print
Wegman, whose Weimaraner dogs appeared in Sesame Street, was influenced by Muybridge. This photo is part of a series charting his dog getting into, onto and out of a box.
displayImages.credit: The J Paul Getty Museum. © William Wegman
displayImages.altText: Out of the Box, 1971, William Wegman, gelatin silver print
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Out of the Box, 1971, William Wegman, gelatin silver print
Wegman, whose Weimaraner dogs appeared in Sesame Street, was influenced by Muybridge. This photo is part of a series charting his dog getting into, onto and out of a box.

displayImages.caption:
Memphis, 1971, William Eggleston, dye imbibition print
Five plastic monochromatic animals march across a scratched stainless surface as though on a determined mission to plunge off the edge at left. Save for a small rectangle of blue at the top center of the image, the brightly-colored plastic animals stand in stark relief against the cool, steel-gray surface.
displayImages.credit: The J Paul Getty Museum/The J Paul Getty Museum. © Eggleston Artistic Trust
displayImages.altText: Memphis, negative, 1971; print, 1974, William Eggleston, dye imbibition print
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Memphis, 1971, William Eggleston, dye imbibition print
Five plastic monochromatic animals march across a scratched stainless surface as though on a determined mission to plunge off the edge at left. Save for a small rectangle of blue at the top center of the image, the brightly-colored plastic animals stand in stark relief against the cool, steel-gray surface.

displayImages.caption:
Goodbye to a Horse, 1993, Keith Carter, gelatin silver print
In his series Heaven of Animals, Keith Carter explored the relationship between humans and animals. He wrote, “both possess sentient power and spiritual presence. Yet each harbors the secret of an inner life that the other will never know.”
displayImages.credit: The J. Paul Getty Museum. Gift of Daniel Greenberg and Susan Steinhauser. © Keith Carter
displayImages.altText: Goodbye to a Horse, 1993, Keith Carter, gelatin silver print
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Goodbye to a Horse, 1993, Keith Carter, gelatin silver print
In his series Heaven of Animals, Keith Carter explored the relationship between humans and animals. He wrote, “both possess sentient power and spiritual presence. Yet each harbors the secret of an inner life that the other will never know.”

displayImages.caption:
Africanis 17. Danielskuil, Northern Cape, 2010, Daniel Naudé, chromogenic print
On a trip from Cape Town to Mozambique, Daniel Naudé came across packs of wild dogs on the plains of the Karoo, a desert like region in South Africa. This encounter led to numerous return visits to track, follow, and observe these feral animals. After developing a bond with a number of them, he photographed them in close proximity. This image is reminiscent of the equestrian portrait tradition popular during the seventeenth century.
displayImages.credit: Daniel Naud/The J Paul Getty Museum
displayImages.altText: Africanis 17. Danielskuil, Northern Cape, 25 February, 2010, 2010, Daniel Naudé, Chromogenic print
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Africanis 17. Danielskuil, Northern Cape, 2010, Daniel Naudé, chromogenic print
On a trip from Cape Town to Mozambique, Daniel Naudé came across packs of wild dogs on the plains of the Karoo, a desert like region in South Africa. This encounter led to numerous return visits to track, follow, and observe these feral animals. After developing a bond with a number of them, he photographed them in close proximity. This image is reminiscent of the equestrian portrait tradition popular during the seventeenth century.

cards.title: The Dozen / The best photos from the last day of the Premier League season
cards.rawTitle: The best photos from the last day of the Premier League season

item.title: The Dozen: the best photos from the last day of the Premier League season
item.trailText: We round up our favourite pictures from Sunday’s matches in the English top flight, the final matches of the 2014/15 season
item.standFirst: We round up our favourite pictures from Sunday’s matches in the English top flight, the final matches of the 2014/15 season

displayImages.caption: The QPR goalkeeper, Alex McCarthy, lies dejected after failing to stop a shot from Leonardo Ulloa. It wasn’t a good day for QPR as the Foxes won 5-1. Photograph: Dan Mullan/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: QPR keeper Alex McCarthy lies dejected after failing to stop a shot from Leicester City's Leonardo Ulloa
displayImages.cleanCaption: The QPR goalkeeper, Alex McCarthy, lies dejected after failing to stop a shot from Leonardo Ulloa. It wasn’t a good day for QPR as the Foxes won 5-1.

displayImages.caption: Spurs’ Nacer Chadli leaps over the challenge of Everton’s John Stones during Tottenham’s 1-0 win at Goodison, which came courtesy of a 24th minute goal by Harry Kane. Photograph: Jan Kruger/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Spurs' Nacer Chadli leaps over the challenge of Everton's John Stones during Tottenham's 1-0 win at Goodison, which came courtesy of a 24th minute goal by Harry Kane
displayImages.cleanCaption: Spurs’ Nacer Chadli leaps over the challenge of Everton’s John Stones during Tottenham’s 1-0 win at Goodison, which came courtesy of a 24th minute goal by Harry Kane.

displayImages.caption: Crystal Palace’s Wilfried Zaha slips through the challenges of Swansea’s Jack Cork and Modou Barrow during the Eagles’ 1-0 win. The Palace winner was scored Marouane Chamakh, his first league goal since September, and the victory saw them finish 10th with a record points tally. Photograph: Alex Broadway/Action Images
displayImages.altText: Crystal Palace’s Wilfried Zaha slips through the challenges of Swansea’s Jack Cork and Modou Barrow during the Eagles’s 1-0 win. The Palace winner was scored Marouane Chamakh, his first league goal since September, and the victory saw them finish 10th with a record points tally
displayImages.cleanCaption: Crystal Palace’s Wilfried Zaha slips through the challenges of Swansea’s Jack Cork and Modou Barrow during the Eagles’ 1-0 win. The Palace winner was scored Marouane Chamakh, his first league goal since September, and the victory saw them finish 10th with a record points tally.

displayImages.caption: Fabian Delph of Aston Villa barges in to Burnley’s Ashley Barnes during the visitors’ 1-0 win at Villa Park. An early goal from Danny Ings was enough to give relegated Burnley victory, their third away win of the season and Villa’s eighth home defeat of the campaign. Photograph: David Jones/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Fabian Delph of Aston Villa barges in to Burnley's Ashley Barnes during the visitors 1-0 win at Villa Park.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Fabian Delph of Aston Villa barges in to Burnley’s Ashley Barnes during the visitors’ 1-0 win at Villa Park. An early goal from Danny Ings was enough to give relegated Burnley victory, their third away win of the season and Villa’s eighth home defeat of the campaign.

displayImages.caption: Farewell Frank. After 609 Premier League appearances for West Ham United, Chelsea and Manchester City, Frank Lampard is off to play in the MLS for New York City FC. The midfielder signed off in style with a typical goal, rifling home James Milner’s cut-back from ten yards out to help Man City beat Southampton 2-0. Photograph: Shaun Botterill/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Farewell Frank. After 609 Premier League appearances by Frank Lampard for West Ham United, Chelsea and Manchester City is off to play in the MLS for New York City FC. . The midfielder signed off in style with a typical goal, rifling home James Milner's cut-back from ten yards out to help Manchester City beat Southampton 2-0
displayImages.cleanCaption: Farewell Frank. After 609 Premier League appearances for West Ham United, Chelsea and Manchester City, Frank Lampard is off to play in the MLS for New York City FC. The midfielder signed off in style with a typical goal, rifling home James Milner’s cut-back from ten yards out to help Man City beat Southampton 2-0.

displayImages.caption: Goodbye Gerrard. After turning out for the 710th time for Liverpool, Steven Gerrard removes the captain’s armband for the last time. Like Lampard, Gerrard is off to MLS but will be on the west coast, turning out for LA Galaxy. Gerrard also scored on his final Premier League game but the result was markedly different with Liverpool tonked 6-1 by Stoke City. Photograph: John Powell/Liverpool FC via Getty Images
displayImages.credit: John Powell/Liverpool FC via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Goodbye Gerrard. After turning out for the 710th time for Liverpool, Steven Gerrard removes the captain's armband for the last time.  Like Frank Lampard, Gerrard is off to MLS but will be on the West Coast, turning out for LA Galaxy. Like Frank Lampard, Gerrard scored on his final Premier League game but the result was markedly different with Liverpool being tonked 6-1 by Stoke City
displayImages.cleanCaption: Goodbye Gerrard. After turning out for the 710th time for Liverpool, Steven Gerrard removes the captain’s armband for the last time. Like Lampard, Gerrard is off to MLS but will be on the west coast, turning out for LA Galaxy. Gerrard also scored on his final Premier League game but the result was markedly different with Liverpool tonked 6-1 by Stoke City.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: John Powell/Liverpool FC via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Arsenal’s Theo Walcott fires a shot into the top corner to open the scoring at the Emirates where Arsenal played host to West Brom. The Gunners ran out 4-1 winners with Walcott, making his first club start for more than two months, bagging a first half hat-trick. Photograph: Dominic Lipinski/PA
displayImages.altText: Arsenal's Theo Walcott fires a shot into the top corner to open the scoring at the Emirates where Arsenal played host to West Brom.  The Gunners ran out 4-1 winners with Walcott, making his first club start for more than two months, bagging a first half hat-trick
displayImages.cleanCaption: Arsenal’s Theo Walcott fires a shot into the top corner to open the scoring at the Emirates where Arsenal played host to West Brom. The Gunners ran out 4-1 winners with Walcott, making his first club start for more than two months, bagging a first half hat-trick.

displayImages.caption: Joy and relief are etched on the faces of the Newcastle bench, including manager John Carver, left, as they celebrate after Jonás Gutiérrez (not pictured) scored the Magpies’ second goal in a 2-0 win over West Ham. The win meant they escaped relegation to the Championship. Photograph: Darren Staples/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Joy and relief are etched on the faces of the Newcastle bench, including manager John Carver, left, as they celebrate after Jonas Gutierrez (not pictured) scored the Magpies second goal in a 2-0 win over West Ham.  The win meant they escaped relegation to the Championship
displayImages.cleanCaption: Joy and relief are etched on the faces of the Newcastle bench, including manager John Carver, left, as they celebrate after Jonás Gutiérrez (not pictured) scored the Magpies’ second goal in a 2-0 win over West Ham. The win meant they escaped relegation to the Championship.

displayImages.caption: Newcastle’s win meant that Hull City were relegated. Hull manager Steve Bruce looks dejected during their goalless draw against Manchester United, where Hull had two goals disallowed. Photograph: Craig Brough/Action Images via Reuters
displayImages.altText: Newcastle's win meant that Hull City were relegated.  Hull manager Steve Bruce looks dejected during their goal-less draw against Manchester United, which is not surprising as Hull had two goals disallowed
displayImages.cleanCaption: Newcastle’s win meant that Hull City were relegated. Hull manager Steve Bruce looks dejected during their goalless draw against Manchester United, where Hull had two goals disallowed.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Craig Brough/Action Images via Reuters

displayImages.caption: It was a sad day for Hull City staff, players and fans. Photograph: Craig Brough/Reuters
displayImages.altText: It was a sad day for Hull City staff, players and fans
displayImages.cleanCaption: It was a sad day for Hull City staff, players and fans.

displayImages.caption: The football writers’ and PFA player of the year Eden Hazard put his dental worries behind him to start the match against Sunderland. This meant that Hazard has played in every one of this season’s Premier League matches for Chelsea. Photograph: Tom Jenkins
displayImages.altText: The Football Writers and PFA Player of the year Eden Hazard put his dental worries behind him to start the match against Sunderland.  This meant that Hazard has played in every one of this season's Premier League matches
displayImages.cleanCaption: The football writers’ and PFA player of the year Eden Hazard put his dental worries behind him to start the match against Sunderland. This meant that Hazard has played in every one of this season’s Premier League matches for Chelsea.

displayImages.caption: Diego Costa tackles a Sunderland player. Costa’s penalty in the 37th minute put Chelsea back on level pegging after Steven Fletcher’s header threatened to spoil the Champion’s celebrations. Two goals from Loïc Rémy late in the match ensured a winning end to the season for the José Mourinho’s side. Click here for pictures of Chelsea’s title celebrations, and here for pictures of their open-top bus parade. Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

cards.title: Five days of art and music in Israel / Midburn festival in the Negev desert
cards.rawTitle: Midburn festival in the Negev desert

item.title: Midburn festival in the Negev desert
item.trailText: Israel’s version of Nevada’s Burning Man festival concluded on Sunday in the Negev desert. In keeping with the Burning Man tradition, thousands of revellers pitched tents in the desert for five days of art, dance and music, before choosing to burn their exhibits on the last two nights of the festival
item.standFirst: Israel’s version of Nevada’s Burning Man festival concluded on Sunday in the Negev desert. In keeping with the Burning Man tradition, thousands of revellers pitched tents in the desert for five days of art, dance and music, before choosing to burn their exhibits on the last two nights of the festival

displayImages.caption: Now in its second year, the organisers of Midburn seek to create a ‘platform which will allow a communal life style, creativity, art and radical self-expression’ Photograph: Amir Cohen/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Now in its second year, the organisers of Midburn seek to create a ‘platform which will allow a communal life style, creativity, art and radical self-expression’.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Now in its second year, the organisers of Midburn seek to create a ‘platform which will allow a communal life style, creativity, art and radical self-expression’

displayImages.caption: Some 6,000 festivalgoers attended the festival in 2015, transforming the arid desert in southern Israel to an oasis of creativity Photograph: Abir Sultan/EPA
displayImages.altText: Some 6,000 festivalgoers attended the festival in 2015, transforming the arid desert in southern Israel to an oasis of creativity.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Some 6,000 festivalgoers attended the festival in 2015, transforming the arid desert in southern Israel to an oasis of creativity

displayImages.caption: Like its US counterpart, the Midburn festival ‘welcomes and respects the stranger’, and has a core principle of gift giving and radical self-expression Photograph: Abir Sultan/EPA
displayImages.altText: Festival goers in costume walking during the Israel Midburn festival in the Negev desert southern Israel
displayImages.cleanCaption: Like its US counterpart, the Midburn festival ‘welcomes and respects the stranger’, and has a core principle of gift giving and radical self-expression

displayImages.caption: The first Midburn took place in 2014, after about two years of planning. The festival’s 2014 population was 3,000 – meaning the 2015 event was double the size Photograph: Amir Cohen/Reuters
displayImages.altText: The first Midburn took place in 2014, after about two years of planning
displayImages.cleanCaption: The first Midburn took place in 2014, after about two years of planning. The festival’s 2014 population was 3,000 – meaning the 2015 event was double the size

displayImages.caption: A festivalgoer pauses during the festival to look through a telescope to survey the sweeping Negev desert landscape Photograph: Abir Sultan/EPA
displayImages.altText: A festivalgoer pauses during the festival to look through a telescope to survey the sweeping Negev desert landscape
displayImages.cleanCaption: A festivalgoer pauses during the festival to look through a telescope to survey the sweeping Negev desert landscape

displayImages.caption: Intimacy beneath the flags: nothing can be bought or sold at Midburn, including food and beverages. The festival city is intended to be a place of sharing and free exchange within a gifting economy Photograph: Menahem Kahana/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Intimacy beneath the flags: nothing can be bought or sold at Midburn, including food and beverages. The festival city is intended to be a place of sharing and free exchange within a gifting economy.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Intimacy beneath the flags: nothing can be bought or sold at Midburn, including food and beverages. The festival city is intended to be a place of sharing and free exchange within a gifting economy

displayImages.caption: People dance during the Midburn festival at southern Israel. Water is not provided at the event, and festivalgoers are advised to bring five litres of water for each day they are at the desert camp Photograph: Amir Cohen/Reuters
displayImages.altText: People dance during the Midburn festival at southern Israel. Water is not provided at the event, and festivalgoers are advised to bring five litres of water for each day they are at the desert camp.
displayImages.cleanCaption: People dance during the Midburn festival at southern Israel. Water is not provided at the event, and festivalgoers are advised to bring five litres of water for each day they are at the desert camp

displayImages.caption: Midburn is a portmanteau of the Hebrew world for desert and the English word ‘burn’, in reference to the Burning Man festival in Nevada Photograph: Abir Sultan/EPA
displayImages.altText: Midburn is a portmanteau of the Hebrew world for desert and the English word ‘burn’, in reference to the Burning Man festival in Nevada.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Midburn is a portmanteau of the Hebrew world for desert and the English word ‘burn’, in reference to the Burning Man festival in Nevada

displayImages.caption: Israeli body artists embrace at dusk: the 2015 Midburn theme was transcendence, which the organisers described as ‘reaching the boundaries of one’s self and beyond the personal point of perception’ Photograph: Abir Sultan/EPA
displayImages.altText: Israeli body artists embrace at dusk: the 2015 Midburn theme was transcendence, which the organisers described as ‘reaching the boundaries of one’s self and beyond the personal point of perception’.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Israeli body artists embrace at dusk: the 2015 Midburn theme was transcendence, which the organisers described as ‘reaching the boundaries of one’s self and beyond the personal point of perception’

displayImages.caption: Statues, art exhibits, performances, theme camps, art-cars and costumes blossom within the social space created by the Midburn organisers Photograph: Amir Cohen/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Statues, art exhibits, performances, theme camps, art-cars and costumes blossom within the social space created by the Midburn organisers.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Statues, art exhibits, performances, theme camps, art-cars and costumes blossom within the social space created by the Midburn organisers

displayImages.caption: A couple dressed in costumes sit inside a hut during the festival, which takes place near the Israeli kibbutz of Sde Boker Photograph: Menahem Kahana/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: A couple dressed in costumes sit inside a hut during the festival, which takes place near the Israeli kibbutz of Sde Boker.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A couple dressed in costumes sit inside a hut during the festival, which takes place near the Israeli kibbutz of Sde Boker

displayImages.caption: No sleep for free souls: the Midburn festival comes alive during the night as attendees play with lights during performance art presentations and dance parties Photograph: Abir Sultan/EPA
displayImages.altText: No sleep for free souls: the Midburn festival comes alive during the night as attendees play with lights during performance art presentations and dance parties.
displayImages.cleanCaption: No sleep for free souls: the Midburn festival comes alive during the night as attendees play with lights during performance art presentations and dance parties

kicker.title: Five days of art and music in Israel
